duplicity.definition: acting in bad faith; deception by pretending to entertain one set of intentions while acting under the influence of another

debonair.definition: having a cheerful, lively, and self-confident air
examples: “"life that is gay, brisk, and debonair"- H.M.Reynolds”

pinnacle.definition: (architecture) a slender upright spire at the top of a buttress or a tower
the highest level or degree attainable; the highest stage of development
examples: “...catapulted Einstein to the pinnacle of fame”

pinnacle.definition: raise on or as if on a pinnacle
examples: “He did not want to be pinnacled”

jaundice.definition: yellowing of the skin and the whites of the eyes caused by an accumulation of bile pigment (bilirubin) in the blood; can be a symptom of gallstones or liver infection or anemia
affect with, or as if with, jaundice

indifference.definition: the trait of remaining calm and seeming not to care; a casual lack of concern
the trait of lacking enthusiasm for or interest in things generally
apathy demonstrated by an absence of emotional reactions

examples: “the disheartened instructor tried vainly to arouse their interest”

wanton.definition: casual and unrestrained in sexual behavior
indulge in a carefree or voluptuous way of life
waste time; spend one's time idly or inefficiently

arrogate.definition: seize and take control without authority and possibly with force; take as one's right or possession
demand as being one's due or property; assert one's right or title to

flummox.definition: be a mystery or bewildering to

dispassionate.definition: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice
examples: “a journalist should be a dispassionate reporter of fact”

chimera.definition: a grotesque product of the imagination

solecism.definition: a socially awkward or tactless act

examples: “"do something rash that he will forever repent"- George Meredith”

rash.definition: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences
examples: “a rash attempt to climb Mount Everest”

rash.definition: any red eruption of the skin
a series of unexpected and unpleasant occurrences

perquisite.definition: an incidental benefit awarded for certain types of employment (especially if it is regarded as a right)
a right reserved exclusively by a particular person or group (especially a hereditary or official right)

quail.definition: flesh of quail; suitable for roasting or broiling if young; otherwise must be braised
draw back, as with fear or pain

examples: “"a prissy and emotionless creature...settles into a mold of desiccated snobbery"-C.J.Rolo”

begrudge.definition: be envious of; set one's heart on

arch.definition: (architecture) a masonry construction (usually curved) for spanning an opening and supporting the weight above it
a passageway under a curved masonry construction
examples: “they built a triumphal arch to memorialize their victory”

arch.definition: a curved shape in the vertical plane that spans an opening
a curved bony structure supporting or enclosing organs (especially the inner sides of the feet)
(used of behavior or attitude) characteristic of those who treat others with condescension

effervescent.definition: used of wines and waters; charged naturally or artificially with carbon dioxide
marked by high spirits or excitement

pragmatic.definition: of or concerning the theory of pragmatism
guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory
an imperial decree that becomes part of the fundamental law of the land

equivocal.definition: open to two or more interpretations; or of uncertain nature or significance; or (often) intended to mislead
examples: “the officer's equivocal behavior increased the victim's uneasiness”
“an equivocal response to an embarrassing question”

equivocal.definition: uncertain as a sign or indication
examples: “the evidence from bacteriologic analysis was equivocal”
“"his conscience reproached him with the equivocal character of the union into which he had forced his son"-Anna Jameson”

iconoclast.definition: someone who attacks cherished ideas or traditional institutions
a destroyer of images used in religious worship

eponym.definition: the person for whom something is named
examples: “Constantine I is the eponym for Constantinople”

eponym.definition: the name derived from a person (real or imaginary)
examples: “Down's syndrome is an eponym for the English physician John Down”

badger.definition: sturdy carnivorous burrowing mammal with strong claws; widely distributed in the northern hemisphere

uncanny.definition: suggesting the operation of supernatural influences
examples: “"stumps...had uncanny shapes as of monstrous creatures"- John Galsworthy”

apostate.definition: not faithful to religion or party or cause
a disloyal person who betrays or deserts his cause or religion or political party or friend etc.

cadaverous.definition: of or relating to a cadaver or corpse
examples: “we had long anticipated his cadaverous end”

cadaverous.definition: very thin especially from disease or hunger or cold
